Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2010 09:02AM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: I have a young friend from the Komen message boards who was diagnosed at the age of 19 last year.  Breaks my heart, but she is doing ok and is becoming a force in advocacy.  My daughter's friend was diagnosed at the age of 30 a year ago and took the time to meet with a fertility expert, and have eggs harvested before she began her treatment.  There is a young girl, (10) I believe in Arizona who was diagnosed.  This is no longer a disease for old women and we really need to make certain our doctors are educated.  Too many are turned away because their primary doctors do not take them seriously when they voice their concerns.  Adrienne was fortunate enough to have pushed hard for some answers and was diagnosed before it advanced very far.  Living Beyond Breast Cancer also has a group for young women.  You young ladies have so many different issues that need to be considered when coming up with a treatment plan, but there are many doing very well several years later.  I have a Komen buddy who was diagnosed in her early 30's, with 22 positive lymph nodes, and 23 years later, she is doing outstandingly well.  There is life after breast cancer, just take everything one day at a time, and you will get through this.  God bless you and keep you safe.
Posts.Title: Is anybody else as young as i am? sumby nmiller

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2010 06:12AM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: My mom took DES when she was pregnant with me.  I seemed to avoid the gynecological issues, but it was something I was very aware of and made choices accordingly.  I never took birth control pills because of the DES exposure, but I still ended up being diagnosed with breast cancer.  I have not found a source that lists DES exposure as a definite risk factor for breast cancer, it lists it as being studied but undetermined, but it certainly makes you wonder.  I had no family history and basically no other risk factors, but was diagnosed at the age of 47.  However, my mom, has never had an abnormal mammogram. Just things that make you go hmmm.
Posts.Title: DES Expsoure and Increased Cancer Risk Ezscriiibe NativeMainer

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2010 06:54AM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: I bought a really snug zip front Champion sports bra for my biopsies, and it works really well for me. I wore it a few days before to get it stretched out enough that it wasn't difficult to put on. Putting ice between the sports bra and the bandage really cut down on swelling and pain.  The first time I was biopsied, I hiked the following day.  The second one, I worked my retail job the following day.  As long as you walk and don't allow a lot of pulling, you would probably be fine walking a dog.  However, I am right handed and my biopsys were on the left, so that made a difference in my ability to use that arm.  If you call your primary care doctor, they may be able to call in a script for a anti anxiety med so that you can avoid an office visit.  I've never needed one but you do whatever you need to in order to get through.  For me, because of neck, back and joint issues, I took a fair amount of ibuprophen before so that I didn't lock up.  Will be wishing you benign results.
Posts.Title: ?'s about biopsy redspark3 redspark3

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2010 06:00AM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: It could be a seroma or a hematoma that needs to be drained.  I had a hematoma that resolved itself, but I have friends who have had to go in and have fluid aspirated out of their breasts.  Some have commented about a sloshing sound in the affected breast.  Hope you get some answers soon.
Posts.Title: Anyone have this happen 2 weeks after a core biopsy? mdoak IronJawedBCAngel

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2010 01:42PM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: If you have inflammatory breast cancer, they are going to try to be as thorough as possible.  Its very aggressive and requires immediate response.  I know several women from Kentucky go all the way to MD. Anderson for their IBC treatment as they seem to be well above many others in the treatment of that disease.  It just doesn't act like other breast cancers and can be tricky to treat. IBC is automatically a Stage III no matter how early it is caught. Because of the IBC, I think I would really question using a local facility to treat your cancer.In regards to your diagnosis, I think I would be considering filing for short term disability so that you can put all of your energy into fighting this disease. I have friends that have had things light up on scans, only to have the PET scan and get the alls clear.  It is very stressful for you, I know and I am sorry you are having to go through this.  Degenerative disease is normally from day to day stress on your body, old injuries etc. and may very well not have anything to do with cancer.  Do you have a cancer resource center nearby?  Many times they are great about helping you understand test results.  John Hopkins also has a great "ask the expert" service.  I used them several times in my early stage of diagnosis and they were extremely helpful. I genuinely hope that your PET scan proves these areas to be from old injuries and calcifications.
Posts.Title: Bone scan results, what does this mean? anetnut mrsnjband

Posts.Content: May 5, 2010 10:11AM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: If you only had mammograms in the past, it is very possible that the mammos saw nothing with your  dense breasts, but were already "busy".  I get an annual MRI in addition to my mammogram as my breasts are also dense and "busy". Hopefully all of the other things the MRI saw are due to benign causes.  However, it is good that they are being thorough and testing all of these things before you begin treatment so that they can design the best treatment plan for you.  Good luck today.
Posts.Title: More tests - Ugh! Houndmommy Lisa1962

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2010 06:51AM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: Wanting to wish you good luck today and benign results.  Most lumps are due to benign causes, so hopefully you will get a good report.  Unfortunately, having a family history is a fairly small percentage of those who get diagnosed with breast cancer.  I had no family history, its just one of those things you learn in increasing awareness.  Too many of us who are "too young" or without family history have ignored symptoms.  I am glad you are getting this checked out.  I have had three biopsies and am a big believer in using ice to keep pain and inflamation down. I put it between my sports bra and the bandage and have always done really well.  Saying some prayers for you.
Posts.Title: Biopsy today shellbell74 Inspireme

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2010 01:57PM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: Just wanted to say that I am sorry you ladies are going through all of this stress.  Its the hardest part of all of this experience and I do pray for those that are still waiting that you get benign results. I have a hard time grasping why it would take two weeks to get results.  When I was diagnosed I got my results the same day.  Had a biopsy last November, different facility, benign thank God but they called me the next day with my results.  It just sucks that you have to wait as long. Laurakay, Take a deep breath and try to stay focused on some positives.  The survival rate for breast cancer caught early is 98%, it is not the death sentence it used to be.  Most of us get through treatment just fine and go on to live full and happy lives.  It is not something I would have chosen for myself but I am being honest when I say my life is much better now and I have been so blessed in the people I have met and the experiences I have had since being diagnosed.  It is the scariest at the point you are at right now when there are so many unknowns, it gets much better when you have a plan.  Education is key to making informed choices so take the time to ask questions and learn all that you need to make the best decisions for yourself.  You are in my prayers. Blessings to all of you.
Posts.Title: Waiting for core biopsy results and scared nancyjg nicole1

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2010 01:09PM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: I'm very sorry to hear that you got bad news for your results.  Please let us know when you are ready to talk.  Prayers for you and your family.
Posts.Title: Waiting for core biopsy results and scared nancyjg nicole1

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2010 01:01PM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: I don't know your story.  What color is the discharge?  I have had discharge from both breasts since I was in my early 20's.  Didn't get diagnosed with breast cancer until almost 5 years ago.  I still have discharge in the "good" breast and have had two biopsies (one on each breast) since diagnosis and they were both benign, the discharge is due to benign breast disease.  I know you are frustrated and scared, but take a deep breath and hope that they get a better picture of what is going on with the MRI.  I would have been ticked off too after the day you had.  I guess under the circumstances I don't understand why they didn't send you directly for the MRI rather than making you wait.  You will be in my prayers for benign findings.
Posts.Title: No surgery today...fluid now leaking from 2 ducts? Chancesmom CrunchyPoodleMama

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2010 09:16AM - edited Jan 16, 2010 09:17AM by IronJawedBCAngel Liz, Getting a second opinion is usually a very good thing.  If they find DCIS in multiple areas, I think the usual protocol is a mastectomy, unless the areas are really close together.  However, don't buy trouble for something that may be benign breast disease or old calcifications from when you bumped your breast 20 years ago.  Go on your vacation, enjoy your life.  My attitude on all of this stuff is that we are all going to die someday and I could very well get hit by a bus tomorrow, so why waste a moment worrying about something I have no control over.  I am due for my annual mammo and will have to have a followup MRI on my misbehaving right breast in a few months, but at this moment, on this wonderful day, I do not have cancer!  and it will never have me. I don't get to this site all that often.  My email is sassyj22000@yahoo if you want to talk. Enjoy your weekend.  Winetasting for me today :)
Posts.Title: MRI guided biopsies? liztaylor1 MTwoman

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2010 12:04PM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: I haven't found the same resource on this site, but if you go to the Komen website, top left corner of the home page, click on the "I've been diagnosed with breast cancer" icon, click on Diagnosis, on left side of page, scroll down to Questions for Providers, I believe that first list is for biopsies.  I used their questions lists for several of my doctors.  They can be printed off in PDF form and are really convenient.  You need to know what type of biopsy is being scheduled, stereotactic, MRI guided, excisional?  If you are an anxious type personality, you might want to ask about getting an anti anxiety med to get you through the procedure.  If it is a stereotactic or MRI and you have back issues, you need to ask if they provide plenty of pillows for cushioning, or if you need to bring your own.  I needed to take a large dose of anti inflammatory and a muscle relaxer as I have a real problem with pressure points and the stereotactic really got to me.  I had an MRI guided last Nov. and the cushioning was better and it was just more comfortable for me.                                                   I bought a front closed sports bra for my biopsies and really liked it, not as much stretching sore breast tissue to get into it.  I will be sending you benign prayers.
Posts.Title: Questions to ask before testing Redbarb804 Leah_S

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2010 08:14AM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: Liz, Tried to respond yesterday and I guess I had used up my quota of posts.  I had a MRI guided biopsy for a fairly large area of enhancement on my "good" breast in November.  It was the best cancer related medical experience I have had.  Almost five years ago, I was diagnosed with DCIS with a stereotactic biopsy, and that biopsy was a nightmare.  The MRI guided was much more comfortable for me, absolutely no pain, just a little sting when they started numbing me.  I do fine with the MRI's so I didn't take any anti anxiety meds, but you do what you need to do to get through this with the least amount of stress.  They had to do another MRI with me as the original was done at a different facility and was of poor image quality and that took the longest.  The actual collection of samples seemed to take very little time.  I was blessed with benign results, and I wish the same for you.  A lesion just refers to an abnormality in the tissue that the MRI detected.  While it can be cancer, it can also be old injuries, benign breast disease, radiation scar tissue, etc.  Did they do an MRI when you were first diagnosed,?  It truly sucks that you are having to deal with another scare so close to your treatment.  God bless you, benign prayers coming your way.
Posts.Title: MRI guided biopsies? liztaylor1 MTwoman

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2010 10:23AM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: I get irritated with stories like yours as the ACS and Komen have recommended MRI's at the time of initial diagnosis for the past several years, but many doctors are still not asking for them.  Hopefully, you have some benign breast disease that it showing up, but I hate that you are having to deal with it at all.  How old are you?   I was diagnosed at the age of 47 and my breasts are still really dense, so I have an annual MRI in addition to my mammo, something you might consider after you get through this latest glitch.  Totally understand the glass of wine, think I did the same :)
Posts.Title: MRI guided biopsies? liztaylor1 MTwoman

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2010 09:15PM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: Just my opinion, but if you ever need another biopsy, I would avoid that facility like the plague.  My MRI guided biopsy taught me that a biopsy does not have to hurt, and I am pretty sure it had to do with the facility and the people doing the biopsy.  I will never return to the facility that did the stereotactic biopsy that diagnosed me.  I don't understand them tying your arms down unless they expected to hurt you.  I pray that you get benign results and a long break from any more medical procedures.
Posts.Title: MRI guided biopsies? liztaylor1 MTwoman

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2010 08:05AM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: Rosemary, I am so sorry you are having this worry on top of the grief of losing your father.  Going without the pepper for a period of time would not have had any bearing on getting cancer.  Unless its an extremely rare, aggressive form, most cancers take a period of years to develop to the point of being detectible, so please do not stress yourself further about whether more pepper or tumeric would have prevented this.  Some cancers have specific characteristics that radiologists read, and your films may be exhibiting some, but until they actually read those biopsy results, they can not be sure it is cancer.  If it is cancer, while it is not a walk in the park, its all very doable.  Even in cases with grim prognosis, some do very well.  I have a friend who had 22 positive nodes when she was diagnosed with triple negative breast cancer, and she will be a 23 year survivor this year.  Another friend who everything was also very grim as far as her doctors were concerned, and taking into consideration what treatments were available when she was diagnosed, and she will be a 55 year survivor this spring.  You are in the worst stage of the fear of the unknown, and I can tell you it does get better.  I have a friend who lives in Ireland and volunteers with me for Komen, Livestrong and other breast cancer organizations.  I will check with her and she may have some friends close to you who have been through it and can help you, even if it is just by listening.  God bless you and I will pray for benign results..
Posts.Title: Scared and Alone Rosemary349 Rosemary349

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2010 01:45PM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: lilmisspinky, I have sent you a private message.
Posts.Title: Women with Breast Cancer Read Please lilmisspinky IronJawedBCAngel

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2010 01:18PM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: The invasive ductal carcinoma is the type of breast cancer cell found in your mom's pathology, you may also hear it referred to as infiltrating.  It is the most common type of bc, about 80% of all bc is this type. Dimpled skin can be an indicator of invasive bc.  The fact that it is not orange peel is a good thing, many inflammatory breast cancers show up first with orange peel skin as a symptom. Tubule formation is part of the equation they use in establishing grade, it is the percent of carcinoma composed of tubular structure.  Less than ten is normally graded as 3. Mitosis is how fast the cells are dividing.  Hers are dividing slowly, which is good, score 1. Nottingham score is a modification of the Schaff Bloom Richardson score and is based on tumor size, grade and # of lymph nodes involved.  Hers would be considered an intermediate grade cancer.  Mine was grade III, or high grade.  The higher the grade, the more aggressive the cancer cell. Her cancer is hormone positive, which means that they will probably recommend tamoxifen or an aromatase inhibitor, like Arimidex, so that the hormones in her body do not feed the cancer cells. She does not have an overexpression of the Her2 gene,(causes excessive growth), which is good, so she will not need Herceptin. T1 means that her tumor size is less than 2cm. I am not a doctor so this is definitely the condensed version.  This site has a good section on understanding pathology and the ACS has a good guide which includes a decision tree for treatment guidelines for breast cancer patients. God bless you and your mother, and I hope she tolerates her treatment well.
Posts.Title: Help me understand this report! Stillshell limegreen

Posts.Content: May 14, 2010 12:07PM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: Komen has a really good list of questions (depending on the health care provider) that you can print off and take with you.  I used those questions on many occasions in those first several months before and after I was diagnosed. If you go to Komen's home page, upper left corner, there is an icon for "I've been diagnosed with breast cancer".  If you click on that it will prompt you through to the resource section and list of questions.  The tape recorder is a good idea in lieu of someone to accompany you.  Your internist probably did not mean to scare you to death.  The fact remains that no one can diagnose cancer just by looking at a mammogram or other diagnostic.  A biopsy is required to actually test the cells and have a pathology lab render a report.  However, some cancers have distinct features that indicate more reason to worry than others.  Your internist was probably wanting you to take this seriously and not put off any follow-up.  When I was diagnosed, the pathologist called and kept repeating that it was really important for me to get an appointment with a surgeon ASAP.  I think there are some women that put it off because of those 80% benign stats.  There are some benign conditions that can result in a suspicious feature showing on a diagnostic test, so don't buy trouble and diagnose yourself before the pathology report comes in.  I have had two biopsies since being diagnosed 5 years ago, and both were benign.  I will be praying for the same outcome for you.

Posts.Title: is there a difference in a breast dedicated mri and regular mri? heyjude62 IronJawedBCAngel

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2010 10:41AM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: Helen, Glad you have the scan scheduled.  Hopefully you will get some answers and can move forward to dealing with it and feeling better. For the fibromyalgia ladies, do you have severe foot pain?  My PC started treating me as if I had fibro the year after I was diagnosed with cancer.  I was having all kinds of pain issues and was not sleeping because of the pressure points. He prescribed me a muscle relaxer before bed and a strong anti inflammatory for morning.  I had also developed plantar faciitis (sp) as I had taken a retail job.  My onc was irritated, said that fibromyalgia is what doctors say when they have no answers.  Once my sleep pattern re-established I felt a lot better and gradually got my quality of life back. I too have major insurance/financial issues and have gone off of every med my doctors have recommended except for my tamoxifen. I take care of my Dad who has advanced colon cancer, s that is a major stressor. In the last several months my pain has elevated, but particularly in my feet.  I look like I am 90 years old.  I am just wondering if this is another fibromyalgia related pain or something else like the 20 lbs I've gained since being diagnosed.  Just another day in bc paradise.  Grateful for each day, but sure would like to be able to move freely again.  I will also say that if you do get diagnosed with fibromyalgia, be aware that the auto immune diseases can cluster; once you get one, others may follow.  I had really nice skin before bc.  I now have psoriasis on several areas, again auto immune related.  Several of my friends on Komen have Rheumatoid Arthritis now. Helen, I truly hope you don't officially join the breast cancer survivor sisterhood and that they find benign reasons for all of your pain and the breast issues. While I worry about the itching and pain, maybe it is something as simple as the bra you wear, I had one that broke me out.  If you do not get answers on the breast issues, keep pushing for answers. Blessings to all.

Posts.Title: is there a difference in a breast dedicated mri and regular mri? heyjude62 IronJawedBCAngel

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2011 03:52PM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: Mammos are not all that effective in dense breasts, which is part of the reason most women do not start being screened until the age of 40.    Your breasts are more dense, so an MRI is probably the best screening tool for you at this time.  There is a lot of information supporting that point of view, so too bad if it annoyed your doctors.  Do a search, print out some of the information on MRIs and dense breasts, and take it in when you go for your followup.  I have no knowledge about disappearing densities, but hope your MRI is clear.
Posts.Title: Disappearing Density?? batty IronJawedBCAngel

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2011 01:43PM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: Have you had a MRI?  Mammograms typically are not very effective with dense breasts.  Most do not experience any symptoms, but some do experience pain and other symptoms, so that is not an absolute.  Hopefully this is some type of infection, but you do need to push for answers.  His theory of scar tissue does not address the pain, swelling and redness.  I have scar tissue, I do not have any of those symptoms.  Wishing you benign results.
Posts.Title: cant sleep danie22 SarahsMom

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2010 04:10PM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: I am not going to tell you not to research, as that is what helped me before I was even diagnosed to have informed conversations with my doctors.  However, stick to the reputable sites, this one, Susan G.Komen, Living Beyond Breast Cancer, and ACS.  If you do suspect IBC, ask for a punch skin biopsy as I have two friends who were diagnosed with that when nothing showed up on any diagnostic.  I would not take a wait and see attitude if that is what the doctors recommend, insist on the skin punch biopsy before following that route.  IBC is a different animal and does not act like other cancers.  I have friends who are IBC survivors and they are doing very well today.  It is good to be looking for a breast cancer surgeon, general surgeons are not always as educated on breast cancer as they should be.  I have seen posts from veterans before,  you may have to fight to access a breast surgeon, but please do so.  If there is any chance that it is IBC, time is of the essence and you can not let them delay you.  There was a post several months back from a young woman who was utilizing the VA intitially but ended up getting approval for using a private breast surgeon.  Hopefully your symptoms are from a benign condition, but definitely get this thoroughly checked out.  God bless you.
Posts.Title: next course of action Deanna67 Deanna67

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2010 11:55AM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: Deanna, I know this is stressful for you, but take a few breaths.  I did a quick look and can not see that you have had an MRI.  An MRI would probably be the normal protocol as the next step diagnostic tool.  You have not had a biopsy yet, am I correct?  Most women I know who have had PET scans ordered are already diagnosed through a biopsy. Some did not get the PET scan until after their surgeries and nodes have been checked. The PET scans, although thorough, are expensive and I think the insurance companies try to reserve them for those who already have a diagnosis and are checking for spread.  It is recommended by ACS and most breast cancer advocacy groups that a bilateral MRI be performed in addition to the mammogram in the diagnostic phase, which is probably what the one woman was referring to when she said "imaging".  Keep pushing for answers, and at this stage I am amazed they have not proceeded to a biopsy so that you are not just dealing with speculation.  All the diagnostic tests in the world will not confirm without a doubt that you have or do not have breast cancer.  You need a biopsy.You continue to be in my prayers.  Take care of yourself.  Take a relaxing soak in the tub, get a massage, surround yourself with humor.  Patience is not a virtue I had when I was diagnosed, but it comes in handy when you are navigating the system.Good luck.
Posts.Title: next course of action Deanna67 Deanna67

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2010 12:46PM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: Glad you are in a location that has an MBI, the closest one here is a seven hour drive for me.  Higher in radiation than MRI, but much cheaper and extremely effective.  You are very fortunate in the location you live!  I'll be interested in what your experience is like as I have been lobbying my facility to get one.
Posts.Title: next course of action Deanna67 Deanna67

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2010 10:45AM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: I had a biopsy in my "good" breast a year ago, pretty much similar path report.  Recommended followup MRI in six months, which I have not had because of insurance/financial issues.  My mammogram was fine this year so I'm playing a little russian roulette with the followup on the biopsy site.  I think a followup biopsy in three months is a little extreme, particularly as the biopsies leave some scar tissue that can lead to some false positives on diagnostics in the future.  Honestly, I was diagnosed originally five years ago, and in all of that time, I don't know anyone who was told to consider a biopsy as a method of followup care on a benign site.  A complete set of diagnostics might be in order, but I also think under the circumstances that I would be seeking out a second opinion as I would be considering changing doctors.  Wishing you a benign future.
Posts.Title: benign results vs repeat biopsy nursing_51 nursing_51

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2010 12:28AM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: Because you are so young, your breasts are very dense and mammography is not a very good tool.  Ultrasound picks up some cancers, and not others.  MRI is the best tool for dense breasts.  With your family history I would not hesitate at all to have the biopsy.  I had a MRI guided biopsy for an area of concern that appeared on my MRI but not on the other diagnostics.  It was benign breast disease.  However there are some benign breast conditions that are red flags for further followup as they are listed as markers for increased risk of developing cancer in that breast.  Either way, I would want to know what is causing the enhancement.  With your BRAC1 status I am amazed they are not taking it more seriously.  Have you given any consideration to removing your ovaries?  I know you are very young and that would be a major step, but have you talked to a genetic counselor about your best options?  You said yourself that you want to be proactive.  I am generally not for surgeries to remove healthy tissue, but the science behind the BRAC positive prophylactic surgeries seems to support those that pursue that path. My surgeon suggested I get the BRAC testing done but have not because of the expense.  Now my daughter is really wanting the information as she is planning on having a reduction and doesn't want to go through all of it and then find out she is positive. I am so sorry for the worry this must cause you.  I will keep you in my thoughts and prayers for benign results.

Posts.Title: is there a difference in a breast dedicated mri and regular mri? heyjude62 IronJawedBCAngel

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2010 11:24AM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: Some cancers do not show up on mammos and dense breasts compound the problem.  Dense breasts alone are a risk factor and your doctors should not be hesitating about ordering a MRI.  I get an annual MRI because of my dense breasts. Find yourself another breast cancer surgeon and if you can, insist on a MRI.  Is the itching deep inside or closer to the surface?  Any changes in the skin on your breast?  There are many benign reasons for breast pain and itching, but you need to have your concerns addressed so that you know. You will be in my prayers.

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2010 10:23AM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: Is there a breast cancer center nearby that you could get a second opinion at?  I know far too many women under the age of 30 who were diagnosed with advanced stage breast cancer because their primary doctor did not believe they could get breast cancer.  I have  a young Komen sister who was diagnosed at the age of 19.  Hopefully it is a cyst, but at the very least I would want an ultrasound to be certain. If there is not a cancer center nearby, I think I would still want a consult with a breast specialist.  If there is a breast cancer support group nearby, they can be really good sources of information on which doctors to go to.  God bless you, and I will be praying for benign results.

Posts.Title: Bone Scan on March 4th,,,,,,Unbelievable. paradiseflower fightinhrd123

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2010 02:18PM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: For me the experience was night and day and I will never go to another hospital to have a breast MRI.  My deductible has skyrocketted since being diagnosed and I have essentially payed out of pocket $3000 dollars to the hospital every year for an MRI since I was diagnosed in 2005.  Last fall, the MRI picked up a suspicious area and my surgeon suggested just following it every 3 months with a complete set of diagnostics at the hospital as my city does not have breast MRI biopsy capability.  That was in Oct. and in my mind the thought of having to pay that amount every 3 months was absurd, so I did a web search, came up with a dedicated breast MRI facility in Nashville and got a second opinion.  When I got there, the first thing I heard the radiologist commenting on was that the quality of the disc from the local hospital was so poor, she really needed to do another MRI before proceeding.  She did the MRI, performed the biopsy, and because of it being at a dedicated breast MRI center independent from any hospital, my insurance paid for it 100%.  I have not booked my annual MRI so I am not sure how much will be covered on the basic diagnostic, but I will be booking my appointment at that same facility in Nashville.  I have had other issues with my local medical community before, and with all of our financial issues, it almost makes me ill to think that we have paid over $12,000 for "poor image quality."  Any diagnostic is only as good as the person reading the test, and so many of these facilities have inadequately trained individuals reading the test that your life depends on. Someone else posted a question about breast MRI not all that long ago, and a MRI expert radiologist posted a response that confirmed my belief that it is definitely worth the extra effort to get to a independent breast MRI facility.  If I can find the post I will post back here so that you can read it also. Just my experience.
Posts.Title: is there a difference in a breast dedicated mri and regular mri? heyjude62 IronJawedBCAngel

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2010 09:01AM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: IBC tends to not show up on some diagnostics.  I have friends who were diagnosed with a simple skin punch biopsy.  I truly hope that your breast issues are due to a benign condition, but keep pushing until you get some answers.  I used to be afraid of needles also but now they really don't bother me very much.  Its just something that is part of the program of trying to stay healthy.  God bless you and give you comfort and healing.
Posts.Title: Possible IBC Mammo and ultrasound today... KimberlyRae KimberlyRae

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2010 10:43AM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: I am so sorry for the run around that you have received from the medical community.  Unfortunately, when it comes to young women, your story is not that unusual.  I have a young Komen sister who found her lump at the age of 24 and could not get anyone to take her seriously, "You're too young"  Three years later when she was finally able to get a doctor to go beyond a clinical breast exam, she was diagnosed with stage IV breast cancer.  Too many doctors are unaware of frequently breast cancer strikes young women. I truly hope that you do not have breast cancer and that they find some other benign cause of all of your problems.  Have you had a breast MRI or a punch skin biopsy?  Keep pushing for the care that you deserve.  God bless you.
Posts.Title: Bone Scan on March 4th,,,,,,Unbelievable. paradiseflower fightinhrd123

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2010 04:11PM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: Don't know if the difference is that the facility in Nashville only does breast MRI, no other kind of MRI, and does a lot of the breast MRI's for patients going to the cancer centers there. Not on par with MD Anderson maybe, but Vanderbilt is pretty well respected. The difference for me is that a hospital provided service (even mammograms) gets billed by my insurance as part of my deductible, so that unless I have met 100% of my $5000 deductible, they do not pay.  My point is that like in your case, it is well worth while to find a facility that you can trust.  I too noticed a big difference in the machines and in the ability of the staff.  The nurses at my local hospital have never been able to get the IV for the contrast in my arm, they blow the veins and end up in a tiny vein in my wrist.  I told the nurse in Nashville to not waste her time, and she laughed and said "Let me give this one try, I do it every day" and sure enough first try, no bruising, no problem.  I genuinely am in love with the women at that facility.  Bonus was absolutely no pain for the biopsy, my stereotactic at the local hospital was a lesson in ancient torture.  Every woman here needs to be their own best advocate and take the time to find the best solutions for themselves.  Blurry diagnostics should not be acceptable at any time, and I really wonder how many of us are aware of image quality.  The discs from the Nashville facility I can put in my own computer and see for myself how clear they are.  The discs from the local facilty have a security incription so that only a medical programmed computer can view them.  I think that should have been my first clue.
Posts.Title: is there a difference in a breast dedicated mri and regular mri? heyjude62 IronJawedBCAngel

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2010 04:31PM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: Sorry for the diagnosis, but at least now they will finally do the biopsy and get started on an action plan.  Rest, recharge, and prepare to come out fighting!  Hugs to you and your husband.  It's a hard road for our co-survivors also.
Posts.Title: next course of action Deanna67 Deanna67

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2010 08:03PM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: Deanna, An excisional biopsy is essentially a lumpectomy.  The tissue will be examined in pathology, and they will really be examining margins at that time.  If the distance of the margin between the cancer cells and the edge of the skin is not great enough, they will do a re-excision to try to get clear margins, or some ladies do choose to get a mastectomy at that time.  The pathology report will also confirm type of cancer cells, grade, hormone receptor status, and Her2 status.  Make sure you ask for copies of your pathology reports.  Mine was an outpatient surgery, I was probably there for about 3 - 4 hours.  In my case the insertion of the wire to the location of the clip marking the biopsy spot was probably the worst part of the whole procedure.  I used ice packs after the procedure, and I was really pretty comfortable.  I didn't take any pain killers after the first day except for ibuprophen.  Recovery was very easy.  I had an excisional the following year on an area that ended up being benign and was back at work the following day. You will be in my thoughts and prayers for a swift recovery and a good pathology report.
Posts.Title: next course of action Deanna67 Deanna67

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2010 04:55PM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: I think I was also typing as you were posting.  I wondered where you lived, and it is just awesome that you are in Houston as MD Anderson is considered one of the leading authorities on IBC.  I have two friends that see their local doctors just to monitor them but they travel to MD Anderson for their care and treatment plans.  So glad to hear that your VA doctor is moving quickly on this.  Let us know what they say.
Posts.Title: next course of action Deanna67 Deanna67

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2010 07:38AM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: Definitely call your doctor today!  While you are young, I have a Komen friend who was diagnosed two years ago at the age of 19 in her first year at Purdue.  It was only because she strongly advocated for herself that she was diagnosed at an early stage.  I have another young friend who found her lump in her early 20's but was not taken seriously until four years later when she was diagnosed Stage IV.  A ten year old was diagnosed last year, so someone with your symptoms should be examined and taken seriously. Hopefully, your symptoms are due to a benign condition, but you definitely need to push for some answers.  As young as you are, a MRI would be more beneficial than a mammogram, but just don't let them pat you on your head and tell you you are too young to worry about it.  Is there a rash where you itch?  Any swelling?  Sometimes a skin punch biopsy should be performed on the itchy area. You will be in my thoughts and prayers for benign results.
Posts.Title: 19 and freaking out lolsatlife Abbey11

Posts.Content: May 27, 2010 06:41PM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: Tori, This is a really scary time, but there are many benign reasons for birad 4, so try not to convince yourself that it is the worst case scenario.  I am a great believer in research and knowledge being power, but I also only go to the reputable sites like bc.org, Komen, Living Beyond Breast Cancer, etc. for information.  If its not on the first several listings of a search page, I didn't go to it. You want knowledge to make informed decisions, you don't need sensational articles to scare you to death. What part of Oklahoma are you living in?  I have a friend from Komen that is a couple year survivor, done all her surgeries and chemo, and is now starting a non-profit that lives near Oklahoma City, I believe.  If you want, send me a Private message and I will put you in contact with her.  It really does help to have support from women who have gone through it.  American Cancer Society has the Reach for Recovery program where they assign you a peer counselor who would be an ear and a shoulder. Cancer is a very scary thing, but keep in mind that the majority of us survive it.  It is not a death sentence like it used to be.  Your mom dying of ovarian cancer was a terrible thing to go through, but it is a different cancer and has not had all the advances that breast cancer has had.  It generally does not get detected until a much later stage because it "whispers".  Hopefully this is benign, but if not, because you have been getting mammograms you have every reason to believe it has been caught early.  God bless you and I will pray for benign results.  Give your pups a hug and enjoy some canine therapy.  If you are completely stressed out, there is nothing wrong with taking the valium or another anti-anxiety med to get through.
Posts.Title: I'm just a mess... ToriGirl Lisa1962

Posts.Content: May 30, 2010 04:39PM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: Wanted to make sure you got the PM with Julie's number.  She's a little crazy, but lots of fun!  Glad you are able to relax a little.  I don't have anyone to go to Sex and the City with so I'll probably have to wait until my daughter comes home in July and see it in the budget theatre.  Have fun!  I'll be thinking of you this week, and wishing benign results.
Posts.Title: I'm just a mess... ToriGirl Lisa1962

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2010 04:37PM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: I had a biopsy for a lump that could be felt, but not seen on any diagnostics.  This was the year after my diagnosis, it was in the axillary area of my affected breast, and they felt it would be irresponsible to not biopsy it.  It was benign radiation scar tissue.  I am not a doctor but cancer cells, tumors have different signatures than benign breast disease, although sometimes they can be very similar, but the radiologists are trained to determine the difference.  With MRI's, cancer cells light up or show enhancement better than fatty tissue or scar tissue.  The fact that nothing showed on the MRI would give me more piece of mind than anything else you have had done.  You could ask about the possibility of having an annual MRI to monitor your breasts in the future. If you are really not comfortable, you could always send your films and discs to another breast specialist for a second opinion.  I know that the implants make screening a challenge.  God bless you and I genuinely hope you never have to join our club of breast cancer survivors.
Posts.Title: lump that doesnt show up on tests hopejess hopejess

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2010 04:23PM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: It's great that you are having the biopsy.  Everything I have been told indicates that BSGI and MBI are the same test.  A study came out a few years ago that was very positive.  My radiologist wants one badly and thought they would have one by now.  The radiation level is higher than a mammogram, but it does not require the same amount of medical expertise to read that an MRI does, hence, the cost is much lower.  I think he told me that he thought $400 would cover the test.  Compared to the $3000 the hospital wants for the MRI, it sounds fairly good as a diagnostic tool for hard to read breasts.  It is not intended to take the place of mammograms, it is a tool in conjunction with.  It is relatively new technology so I don't know if insurance is picking it up, but as my insurance doesn't even pay for my mammograms, that is not a great factor for me.  I have to go help my Dad, but if I have time later I will post a link.

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2010 06:35AM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: My being a DES daughter was not a factor in my treatment plan.  Mine was found extremely early so a mastectomy was never a consideration.  I have an older sister who is also a DES daughter, and she has never had an abnormal mammogram.  I know there are some that believe there is link to breast cancer, but at this point it has not been proven and is still being investigated.
Posts.Title: DES daughters bludevil Huskapet

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2010 09:00AM IronJawedBCAngel wrote: I did not have a mastectomy, so can not give you any advice on reconstruction other than look at the portfolios of the plastic surgeon, and make the best choice with who you feel the most comfortable with.  I have friends who basically interviewed several breast PS, and the ones that took that time and asked all of their questions and made an informed decision are the ones who are most happy with the results of their reconstruction. You have done the best to inform yourself and can only make the decision for yourself based on your criteria.  Those of us who have chosen lumpectomies have done so at the advice of our cancer teams based on years of studies that have proven that the survival rate for early stage cancers with lumpectomy and radiation, and mastectomy are exactly the same. Many studies have also proven that the quality of life for women with lumpectomies is superior to that of those with mastectomies, which is part of the reason lumpectomies became an option after years of automatic mastectomies with a cancer diagnosis.  Five years after my diagnosis, I am far too aware, and am friends with women who chose to have bilateral mastectomies, only to have the cancer come back as a local or distant recurrence.  It sucks, but there are no guarantees.  We inform ourselves, and make the best decision we can, for ourselves. We choose different paths with the same hope that we reach the other side of treatment with a lifelong relationship with NED, No Evidence of Disease. I wish you a swift recovery and hope you too find that "wizard" who creates magic with your reconstruction. God bless you and your son and keep you safe.
